(Sec. 1204) Directs the President to report to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees on authorities of DOD and other federal departments and agencies to build the capacity of foreign military forces, as well as related matters.

Subtitle B: Matters Relating to Iraq, Afghanistan, and Pakistan - (Sec. 1211) Prohibits the use of funds from this Act to: (1) establish any military installation or base for providing for the permanent stationing of U.S. Armed Forces in Iraq; or (2) exercise control of the oil resources of Iraq.

(Sec. 1212) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to: (1) reauthorize through FY2010 the Commanders' Emergency Response Program (urgent humanitarian assistance in Iraq and Afghanistan); (2) provide a FY2010 funding level; and (3) extend into 2010 required quarterly Program reports.

(Sec. 1213) Authorizes the Secretary to reimburse any key cooperating (coalition) country for logistical and military support provided in connection with Operations Iraqi Freedom or Enduring Freedom. Limits to $1.6 billion the total amount that may be provided in FY2010. Requires: (1) the Secretary to notify the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees at least 15 days in advance of any such reimbursement; and (2) quarterly reports from the Secretary to such committees on reimbursements made. Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008 to extend through FY2011 required congressional notification regarding DOD coalition support funds for Pakistan.

(Sec. 1214) Establishes in DOD a Pakistan Counterinsurgency Fund to provide assistance to the security forces of Pakistan to improve their counterinsurgency capabilities. Earmarks Fund amounts to provide humanitarian assistance to the people of Pakistan, but only as part of civil-military training exercises for Pakistani security forces receiving assistance from the Fund. Provides for transfers to and from the Fund. Prohibits amounts from being obligated or transferred from the Fund until 15 days after the Secretary has notified the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees of the purpose of the obligation or transfer. Terminates assistance authority at the end of FY2010.

(Sec. 1215) Directs the Secretary to carry out a program to provide for the registration and end-use monitoring of defense articles and defense services transferred to Afghanistan and Pakistan, and to prohibit the retransfer of such articles and services without U.S. consent. Prohibits the transfer of any such articles or services until the program is established. Outlines registration and end-use monitoring requirements. Directs the Secretary to periodically review the articles and services subject to such registration and monitoring to determine their continued suitability to such requirements. Allows the Secretary to exempt an article or service from such requirements beginning 30 days after notification thereof to the defense and foreign relations committees.

(Sec. 1216) Requires: (1) reports from the CG to the defense and appropriations committees containing assessments of the extent to which the campaign plans for Iraq and Afghanistan each adhere to military doctrine (as outlined in DOD's Joint Operation Planning document); and (2) report updates whenever either campaign plan is substantially updated or altered (with an exception). Terminates on: (1) December 31, 2011, the reports requirement on Iraq; and (2) September 30, 2012, the reports requirement on Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1217) Directs the President to: (1) conduct semiannual assessments on progress toward defeating al Qaida and its affiliated networks and extremist allies, and on preventing the establishment of safe havens in Afghanistan for such entities; and (2) report to Congress 30 days after completing each assessment. Terminates the assessments requirement five years after the enactment of this Act.

(Sec. 1218) Requires quarterly reports from the Secretary to the defense, appropriations, foreign relations, and intelligence committees on the responsible redeployment of U.S. forces from Iraq in accordance with the policy announced by the President on February 27, 2009, and the Agreement Between the United States of America and the Republic of Iraq on the Withdrawal of United States Forces From Iraq and the Organization of Their Activities During Their Temporary Presence in Iraq.

(Sec. 1219) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on the Afghan Public Protection Program.

(Sec. 1220) Amends the Hunter Act to authorize the inclusion in a related report requirement under the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008 updates of a Hunter Act report concerning the command and control structure for military forces operating in Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1221) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on payments made by U.S. Armed Forces to residents of Afghanistan as compensation for losses caused by U.S. military operations. Terminates the report requirement at the end of FY2012.

(Sec. 1222) Requires the Secretary to: (1) assess possible alternatives to reimbursements to Pakistan for logistical, military, or other support provided to or in connection with U.S. military operations; and (2) report assessment results to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees.

(Sec. 1223) Directs the President to: (1) conduct semiannual assessments on progress toward long-term security and stability in Pakistan; and (2) report to Congress 30 days after completing each assessment. Terminates the assessments requirement five years after the enactment of this Act.

(Sec. 1224) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to repeal required quarterly updates from the CG to Congress on the costs of Operations Iraqi Freedom and Enduring Freedom.

(Sec. 1225) Directs the Secretary to: (1) prepare a plan governing the disposition of specified defense items currently in Iraq and no longer necessary to support U.S. military operations there; and (2) report such plan to the defense and appropriations committees. Requires the CG to review the plan and report review results to such committees.

(Sec. 1226) Authorizes the Secretary to provide civilian advisors to senior civilian and military officials of the governments of Iraq and Afghanistan for the purpose of providing advice and other training in support of stabilization efforts and U.S. military operations in those countries. Limits funding for such activities. Terminates such authority at the end of FY2010.

(Sec. 1227) Directs the Secretaries of Defense and State to report to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees on the status of interagency coordination in the Afghanistan and Operation Enduring Freedom theaters of operation.

(Sec. 1228) Expresses the sense of Congress in support of U.S. antiterrorism and counterinsurgency strategy in Afghanistan. Calls for Congress to ensure that U.S. military commanders in Afghanistan have the necessary funding and resources to succeed.

(Sec. 1229) Directs the Secretary to contract with a federally funded research and development center to provide analysis and support to the Commander of United States Forces for Afghanistan of force levels and types of force needed to secure the southern and eastern regions of Afghanistan. Provides funding.

Subtitle C: Other Matters - (Sec. 1231) Earmarks specified Army O&M funds for support of North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) operations, specifically for the NATO Special Operations Coordination Center. Requires the Secretary to certify to the defense committees that the Secretary has assigned executive agent responsibility for the Center to an appropriate organization within DOD.

(Sec. 1232) Requires the Secretary to report to the defense, appropriations, foreign relations, and intelligence committees on the current and future military strategy of Iran.

(Sec. 1233) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2000 to require additional information in an annual report concerning military and security developments involving the People's Republic of China, including U.S. engagement and cooperation with China on security matters, military-to-military contacts, and U.S. strategy for engagement and cooperation in the future.

(Sec. 1234) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees on the impacts of drawdown authorities on DOD.

(Sec. 1235) Requires the Secretaries of Defense and State to jointly: (1) assess the national security risks of removing satellites and related components from the United States Munitions List; and (2) report assessment results to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees.

(Sec. 1236) Directs the Secretary to seek to deploy to Poland by 2012 a U.S. Army Patriot air and missile defense battery and the personnel required to operate and maintain the battery.

(Sec. 1237) Requires the Secretary to report to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees on potential foreign military sales of the F-22A fighter aircraft to Japan.

(Sec. 1238) Authorizes the Secretary to expand the United States-Russian Federation joint center for the exchange of data from early warning systems for launches of ballistic missiles to include the exchange of data on missile defense-related activities. Directs the Secretary to report to the defense committees on plans for expansion of the center. Provides funding.

Title XIII: Cooperative Threat Reduction - (Sec. 1301) Specifies the cooperative threat reduction (CTR) programs to be funded through O&M funds provided under this Act. Makes funds appropriated for such purpose available for three fiscal years. Allocates such funds among specified CTR programs. Prohibits such funds from being used for purposes other than those specified until 30 days after the Secretary reports to Congress on the new purposes. Provides limited authority to vary allocated amounts in the national interest, after congressional notification.

(Sec. 1303) Authorizes the Secretary to enter into an agreement with any person or entity under which the person or entity contributes funds for activities conducted under the CTR program. Requires: (1) the return of amounts not used within five years; and (2) quarterly reports from the Secretary to the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees on the receipt and use of contributed funds. Terminates at the end of: (1) 2012 the authority to accept such contributions; and (2) 2015 the authority to retain and use such contributions.

(Sec. 1304) Directs the Secretary to enter into an agreement with the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) under which NAS carries out a study to identify metrics to measure the impact and effectiveness of CTR activities in addressing threats arising from the proliferation of chemical, nuclear, and biological weapons and weapons-related materials, technologies, and expertise. Requires a report on study results from: (1) NAS to Congress and the Secretary; and (2) the Secretary to Congress. Provides funding.

(Sec. 1305) Prohibits the use of more than 10% of CTR funds in a fiscal year for urgent threat reduction activities until the Secretary notifies the defense, appropriations, and foreign relations committees that such activities are urgently needed to address threats arising from the proliferation of chemical, nuclear, or biological weapons or weapons-related materials, technologies, and expertise.

(Sec. 1306) Directs the Secretary to ensure that the Defense and Military Contacts Program (part of the CTR program): (1) is used to advance the CTR program mission; (2) is focused and expanded to support specific relationship-building opportunities; (3) is directly administered as part of the CTR program; and (4) includes the unified combatant commands that operate in areas in which CTR activities are carried out, as well as related diplomatic affairs. Requires information concerning the strategy and activities of the Contacts Program to be included in the annual CTR program report to Congress under the Floyd D. Spence National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001.

Title XIV: Other Authorizations - Subtitle A: Military Programs - (Sec. 1401) Authorizes appropriations to DOD for FY2010 for: (1) Defense Working Capital Funds; (2) the National Defense Sealift Fund; (3) the Defense Health Program; (4) chemical agents and munitions destruction; (5) drug interdiction and counter-drug activities; and (6) the Defense Inspector General.

Subtitle B: National Defense Stockpile - (Sec. 1411) Authorizes the National Defense Stockpile (NDS) Manager, during FY2010, to obligate up to $41.179 million of the funds in the National Defense Stockpile Transaction Fund (Fund) for authorized Fund uses, including the disposition of hazardous materials that are environmentally sensitive. Authorizes the NDS Manager to obligate amounts in excess of such amount 45 days after notifying Congress that extraordinary or emergency conditions necessitate the additional obligations.

(Sec. 1412) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1998 to extend through FY2011 the authority to dispose of cobalt from the NDS.

(Sec. 1413) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense committees on actions planned in response to recommendations contained in a specified DOD report concerning the reconfiguration of the NDS. Prohibits the Secretary from taking any planned action until 45 days after the submission of such report.

Subtitle C: Armed Forces Retirement Home - (Sec. 1421) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for the Armed Forces Retirement Home.

Title XV: Authorization of Additional Appropriations for Overseas Contingency Operations - (Sec. 1502) Authorizes appropriations for DOD for FY2010 to provide additional funds for overseas contingency operations, specifically for: (1) procurement; (2) the Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Fund; (3) the Mine Resistant Ambush Protected Vehicle; (4) RDT&E; (5) O&M; (6) Defense Working Capital Funds; (7) military personnel; (8) the Afghanistan Security Forces Fund; (9) the Iraq Freedom Fund; (10) the Defense Health Program; (11) drug interdiction and counterdrug activities; and (12) the Defense Inspector General.

(Sec. 1504) Prohibits the obligation of more than 50% of the funds authorized for the Joint Improvised Explosive Devices Defeat Organization until the Organization reports to the defense and appropriations committees concerning the purpose, funding, and schedule of projects. Authorizes the Secretary to waive such limitation when necessary to fulfill a critical need of U.S. military forces deployed in overseas contingency operations.

(Sec. 1516) Makes funds available for FY2010 for the Iraq Security Forces Fund subject to Fund use, transfer, and related limitations prescribed under the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008.

(Sec. 1517) Applies to funds authorized under this title provisions of the Hunter Act prohibiting the use of funds for the acquisition, development, or improvement of facilities in Iraq for use by the Iraqi government, its political subdivisions, or its armed forces.

(Sec. 1518) Authorizes the Secretary, in the national interest, to transfer up to $4 billion of the amounts made available to DOD in this title between any such authorizations for that fiscal year.

(Sec. 1519) Treats amounts authorized by this title as in addition to amounts otherwise authorized by this Act.

Division B: Military Construction Authorizations - Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010 - (Sec. 2002) Terminates all authorizations contained in Titles XXI through XXVII, and Title XXIX of this Act on October 1, 2012, or the date of enactment of an Act authorizing funds for military construction for FY2013, whichever is later, with an exception.

Title XXI [sic]: Army - (Sec. 2101) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects in specified amounts at specified installations and locations. Authorizes such Secretary to construct or acquire family housing units, carry out architectural planning and design activities, and improve existing military family housing in specified amounts. Authorizes appropriations to the Army for fiscal years after 2009 for military construction, land acquisition, and military family housing functions of the Army. Limits the total cost of construction projects authorized by this title.

(Sec. 2105) Provides additional authority for the Secretary with respect to the construction of a military chapel for Fort Bragg, North Carolina, under the Military Construction Authorization Act (MCAA) for Fiscal Year 2009.

(Sec. 2106) Extends certain prior-year military construction projects.

Title XXII: Navy - (Sec. 2201) Provides, with respect to the Navy, authorizations paralleling those provided for the Army under the previous title.

(Sec. 2205) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2006 to increase the amount authorized for a project at the Naval Submarine Base, Bangor, Washington. Extends the authority to carry out such project until October 1, 2010, or the date of enactment of an Act authorizing funds for military construction for FY2011, whichever is later.

Title XXIII: Air Force - (Sec. 2301) Provides, with respect to the Air Force, authorizations paralleling those provided for the Army under Title XXI.

(Sec. 2305) Extends certain prior-year military construction projects.

Title XXIV: Defense Agencies - Subtitle A: Defense Agency Authorizations - (Sec. 2401) Authorizes the Secretary to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects in specified amounts at specified installations and locations. Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for military construction, land acquisition, and military family housing functions of DOD. Limits the total cost of construction projects authorized by this title. Earmarks funds for energy conservation projects for the reserves.

(Sec. 2403) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year: (1) 2008 to increase the amount authorized for a project at the Point Loma Annex, California; and (2) 2009 to increase the amount authorized for a project in Souda Bay, Greece.

(Sec. 2405) Extends a prior-year military construction project.

Subtitle B: Chemical Demilitarization Authorizations - (Sec. 2411) Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for military construction and land acquisition for chemical demilitarization for the construction of: (1) phase 11 of a chemical munitions demilitarization facility at Pueblo Chemical Activity, Colorado; and (2) phase 10 of a munitions demilitarization facility at Blue Grass Army Depot, Kentucky.

Title XXV: North Atlantic Treaty Organization Security Investment Program - (Sec. 2501) Authorizes the Secretary to make contributions for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Security Investment Program and authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for such Program.

Title XXVI: Guard and Reserve Forces Facilities - (Sec. 2601) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects for the National Guard and reserves.

(Sec. 2606) Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for National Guard and reserve forces for acquisition, architectural and engineering services, and construction of facilities.

(Sec. 2607) Extends certain prior-year National Guard and reserve military construction projects.

Title XXVII: Base Closure and Realignment Activities - Subtitle A: Authorizations (Sec. 2701) Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for military base closure and realignment activities authorized under the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 and funded through the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 1990.

(Sec. 2702) Authorizes the Secretary to carry out base closure and realignment activities authorized under the above Act and funded through the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 2005. Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for such purpose.

Subtitle B: Amendments to Base Closure and Related Laws - (Sec. 2711) Amends the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 to replace job generation with economic redevelopment as a purpose of former military installation land conveyances. Provides conditions under which real or personal property at a military installation shall be conveyed to a redevelopment authority. Requires a report from the Secretary to Congress regarding the status of current and anticipated economic development conveyances involving surplus real and personal property at closed or realigned military installations, projected job creation as a result of such conveyances, community reinvestment, and progress made due to the implementation of amendments made by this section.

Subtitle C: Other Matters - (Sec. 2721) Expresses the sense of Congress that, in implementing recommendations of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, the Secretary should ensure that the joint basing of military installations at any of the recommended locations does not adversely affect the operational readiness of applicable military units and the ability of the commanders thereof to perform their mission.

(Sec. 2722) Provides that, with respect to the closure of the Paul Doble Army Reserve Center in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, and the relocation of units to a new reserve center and associated training and maintenance facilities, the new center and facilities may be located adjacent to or in the vicinity of Pease Air National Guard Base.

Title XXVIII: Military Construction General Provisions - Subtitle A: Military Construction Program and Military Family Housing Changes - (Sec. 2801) Eliminates a fiscal year funding limit with respect to exercise-related unspecified minor military construction projects coordinated or directed by the JCS outside the United States.

Allows for the use of certain funds authorized under the Hunter Act to fund the revitalization and recapitalization of defense laboratories.

(Sec. 2802) Requires congressional notification of facility repair projects in excess of $7.5 million using O&M funds to include a comparison of repair versus replacement as well as a description of the construction contemplated in the repair.

(Sec. 2803) Prohibits the scope of work for a military construction project or for the construction, improvement, or acquisition of a military family housing project from being increased beyond the amount approved by Congress (unless Congress is so notified).

(Sec. 2804) Requires the acquisition of reserve facilities to be authorized by law. (Currently, such acquisition is authorized when the Secretary determines it to be necessary.)

(Sec. 2805) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees identifying, for each of FY2005-FY2009, the total payments made to each state for the acquisition, construction, expansion, rehabilitation, or conversion of reserve facilities.

(Sec. 2806) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2004 to extend through FY2010 the use of defense-wide O&M funds for construction projects at locations within the U.S. Central Command area of responsibility. Allows an additional $10 million under such authority if the Secretary determines that such funds are required to complete contract closeouts.

(Sec. 2807) Requires: (1) the Secretary of the Army to expand the First Sergeants Barracks Initiative to include all Army installations in order to improve the quality of life and living environments of single soldiers; and (2) a progress report from such Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 2808) Directs the: (1) Secretary to report to the defense committees on privatization initiatives for military unaccompanied housing; and (2) CG to report to such committees evaluating the feasibility and costs of such privatization for all members of the Armed Forces.

Subtitle B: Real Property and Facilities Administration - (Sec. 2811) Allows the Secretary or the Secretary concerned to enter into a lease for real property whose annual rental is in excess of $750,000 only if such lease is specifically authorized by law. Repeals the current congressional notification requirement with respect to such leases.

(Sec. 2812) Consolidates into one provision, and requires additional information, with respect to notification requirements applicable to leases of real property owned by the United States.

(Sec. 2813) Waives the requirement that a military department obtain authorization by law in order to acquire an interest in real property not owned by the United States when the acquisition is low-cost or when its need is urgent.

(Sec. 2814) Requires, prior to the conveyance of a utility to a private organization for the contract performance of utility services, a determination by the Secretary concerned that such conveyance will realize a cost saving (over performance by DOD personnel) of 10% over a contract period of less than ten years, and 20% over a contract period of more than ten years and less than 50 years. Prohibits a utility privatization review for five years after completion of a public-private competition.

(Sec. 2815) Amends the MCAA, 1974 to remove certain restrictions on environmental remediation on the island of Culebra, Puerto Rico.

(Sec. 2816) Amends the Armed Forces Retirement Home Act of 1991 to require the Secretary to dispose of excess Home property according to procedures followed by the General Services Administration (GSA) for excess federal property.

(Sec. 2817) Authorizes the Secretary of the Air Force to accept contributions from public and private entities for the environmental cleanup of the former Almaden Air Force Station, California.

(Sec. 2818) Prohibits the Secretary of the Navy from establishing an outlying landing field to be used by naval aircraft if, within 90 days after issuance of a final environmental assessment or impact statement regarding its proposed location, the Secretary determines that the appropriate local governmental body is formally opposed to such establishment. Provides an exception if Congress enacts a law authorizing such establishment despite the local opposition.

(Sec. 2819) Prohibits the Secretary of the Navy from undertaking any activities that would facilitate the establishment of an outlying landing field at Sandbanks or Hale's Lake, North Carolina, to support landing practice for naval aircraft operating out of Oceana Naval Air Station, Virginia.

(Sec. 2820) Directs the Secretary of the Army, in selecting installations at which brigade combat teams will be stationed, to consider the availability and proximity of training spaces for the units and the capacity of the installations to support the units.

Subtitle C: Provisions Related to Guam Realignment - (Sec. 2831) Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy to be responsible for coordinating DOD activities in connection with the realignment of military installations and relocation of military personnel on Guam. Makes such Under Secretary also responsible for activities of the Joint Guam Program Office.

(Sec. 2832) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on implementation guidance developed for the use of special purpose entities to assist with the Guam realignment and relocation. Prohibits the Secretary from implementing such guidance until 30 days after the report is submitted. Applies U.S. Unified Facilities Criteria to all projects supported by the Support for United States Relocation to Guam Account, as established under the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2009. Expresses the sense of Congress that utility improvements on Guam should incorporate military and civilian utilities into a unified grid.

(Sec. 2833) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2009 to require: (1) military construction contracts on Guam to comply with federal construction contract requirements; (2) a prevailing wage rate equal to the lowest rate on projects of similar character for Hawaii; (3) a required weekly employment statement to identify each employee working on the project who holds a visa issued under the Immigration and Nationality Act; (4) the Secretary of Labor to make and issue a wage rate determination for projects on Guam annually until 90% of the realignment and relocation funds have been expended; and (5) a required annual report to include an assessment of the living standards of the construction workforce employed to carry out projects on Guam.

(Sec. 2834) Amends the above Act to prohibit more than 30% of the total hours worked per month on a Guam construction project from being performed by persons holding immigration visas. Requires the construction contractor, in order to comply with such requirement, to advertise and solicit for construction workers in the United States and its territories in accordance with a recruitment plan developed by the Secretary of Labor. Requires reports from the Secretaries of Defense and Labor with respect to Guam project labor agreements and the recruitment of U.S. construction workers.

(Sec. 2835) Establishes the Interagency Coordination Group of Inspector Generals for Guam Realignment to provide independent and objective oversight of accounting and related information relating to DOD programs and operations for military construction activities on Guam. Requires an annual report from the Coordination Group to the defense and appropriations committees on its activities and on programs and operations funded from amounts made available for military construction on Guam. Requires each such report to be made available on a publicly-available Internet website, with an authorized waiver by the President for national security reasons. Terminates the Coordination Group upon the expenditure of 90% of the funds available for Guam realignment.

(Sec. 2836) Prohibits the Secretary from accepting, or authorizing any other DOD official to accept, a replacement facility in Okinawa for air operations conducted at the Marine Corps Air Station, Futenma, Okinawa, unless the Secretary certifies to the defense and appropriations committees that the replacement facility satisfies minimum naval aviation safety requirements.

(Sec. 2837) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on training requirements for Marine Corps Pacific, the field command of the Marine Corps within the U.S. Pacific Command. Expresses the sense of Congress that an evaluation of such requirements: (1) should be conducted and completed as soon as possible; (2) should include a training analysis that reviews capabilities required to support a Marine Air-Ground Task Force; and (3) should not impact implementation of a recently-signed international agreement concerning the relocation of certain Marine expeditionary force personnel and their dependents from Okinawa to Guam.

Subtitle D: Energy Security - (Sec. 2841) Directs the Secretary to adopt an open source energy monitoring and management system specification for use throughout DOD in connection with a military construction project, military family housing activity, or other building activity. Allows the Secretary concerned, upon notification to the defense and appropriations committees, to waive such requirement if such Secretary determines that its inclusion in a construction project is not cost effective over the project's life cycle. Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on items associated with the adoption of a single specification for an energy monitoring and management system.

(Sec. 2842) Directs the Secretary concerned or the head of a defense agency, in leasing or procuring motor vehicles, to provide a preference for vehicles using electric or hybrid propulsion systems if such vehicles meet DOD requirements and are commercially available at a reasonable cost. Provides an exception with respect to vehicles designed for use in combat.

(Sec. 2843) Revises the DOD definition of "renewable energy source" to include non-electric energies such as solar and wind power.

(Sec. 2844) Requires a report from the CG to Congress on all renewable energy initiatives being funded by DOD or a military department down to the base commander level.

(Sec. 2845) Directs the Secretary to: (1) study the feasibility of developing nuclear power plants on military installations; and (2) report study results to the defense committees.

Subtitle E: Land Conveyances - (Sec. 2851) Amends the Port Chicago National Memorial Act of 1992 to direct the Secretary to transfer to the Secretary of the Interior specified real property at the Port Chicago Naval Magazine, in order to administer the Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial. Requires the Secretary of the Interior to provide as much public access to the Memorial as possible without interfering with military needs. Expresses the sense of Congress that the: (1) Secretary should remediate remaining environmental contamination at the site; and (2) both Secretaries should develop a process for timely future repairs and necessary modifications to the Memorial.

(Sec. 2852) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to convey to the Hawaii Community Development Authority six parcels of real property at the former Naval Station, Barbers Point, Hawaii.

(Sec. 2853) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2005 to authorize the Secretary of the Air Force to convey an additional parcel of land at the former Griffiss Air Force Base, New York.

(Sec. 2854) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to convey to the Chambersburg Area School District, Pennsylvania, the Army Reserve Center in Chambersburg for educational, educational support, and community activities.

(Sec. 2855) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to convey to Virginia Beach, Virginia, parcels of property at the Naval Air Station Oceana, Virginia, to permit the city to expand services to support the Marine Animal Care Center.

(Sec. 2856) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to convey to the Chilkoot Indian Association specified property at the former Haines Fuel Terminal, Alaska, to permit the Association to develop a deep sea port, and for other industrial and commercial development purposes.

(Sec. 2857) Amends the MCAA for Fiscal Year 2002 to require (under current law, authorizes) the Secretary of the Army to complete a land exchange and consolidation at Fort Lewis, Washington.

Subtitle F: Other Matters - (Sec. 2871) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008 to authorize the Secretary to permit the John Burnam Monument Foundation, Inc. (under current law, authorizes the National War Dogs Monument, Inc.) to establish and maintain a national monument to honor U.S. Armed Forces working dog teams.

(Sec. 2872) Designates the child development center at Fort Wood, Missouri, as the "S. Lee Kling Child Development Center."

(Sec. 2873) Prohibits FY2010 military construction funding from being obligated to commence construction of a cooperative security location at the German Olano Airbase in Palanquero, Colombia, until 15 days after certification from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees that an agreement has been entered into with Colombia that will allow such construction in a manner than enables the U.S. Southern Command to execute its Theater Posture Strategy in cooperation with the armed forces of Colombia.

(Sec. 2874) Amends the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 to provide that the designation of the Bridgeport Winter Recreation Area, California, is not intended to restrict or preclude activities conducted by the U.S. Armed Forces at the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center.

Title XXIX: Overseas Contingency Operations Military Construction Authorizations - (Sec. 2901) Authorizes the Secretary of the Army to acquire real property and carry out military construction projects at specified installations and locations outside the United States in support of overseas contingency operations. Authorizes appropriations for fiscal years after 2009 for military construction, land acquisitions, and military family housing functions of the Army.

(Sec. 2902) Provides, with respect to the Air Force, authorizations paralleling those provided for the Army, above.

(Sec. 2903) Authorizes the Secretary to use specified DOD military construction funds to plan, design, and construct facilities on the U.S. Embassy Compound in Islamabad, Pakistan, in support of the Office of the Defense Representative-Pakistan (ODRP). Requires four semiannual reports from the Secretary to the defense and foreign relations committees on the number of personnel and activities of the ODRP.

Division C: Department of Energy National Security Authorizations and Other Authorizations - Title XXXI [sic]: Department of Energy National Security Programs - Subtitle A: National Security Programs Authorizations - (Sec. 3101) Authorizes appropriations for the Department of Energy (DOE) for FY2010 for: (1) activities of the National Nuclear Security Administration in carrying out programs necessary for national security, with specified allocations for weapons activities, defense nuclear nonproliferation activities, naval reactors, and the Office of the Administrator for Nuclear Security (Administrator); and (2) environmental restoration and waste management activities and plant projects in carrying out national security programs, with specified allocations for defense environmental cleanup, other defense activities, defense nuclear waste disposal, and energy security and assurance.

Subtitle B: Program Authorizations, Restrictions, and Limitations - (Sec. 3111) Amends provisions of the Atomic Energy Defense Act concerning the establishment of the stockpile stewardship program (program) to direct the Secretary of Energy (Secretary, for purposes of this title) to: (1) implement the program through the Administrator; and (2) establish a stewardship program to ensure the preservation of the core intellectual and technical competencies of the United States in nuclear weapons and to ensure that the nuclear weapons stockpile is safe, secure, and reliable without the use of underground testing. Includes as additional program elements material support for: (1) the use of, and experiments facilitated by, specified advanced experimental facilities of the United States; and (2) the sustainment and modernization of facilities with production and manufacturing capabilities necessary to ensure the safety, security, and reliability of the nuclear weapons stockpile. Repeals a provision authorizing program appropriations for FY1994.

(Sec. 3112) Repeals provisions of such Act relating to the reliable replacement warhead program. Replaces the nuclear weapons stockpile life replacement program with the stockpile management program, the latter to provide for effective management of weapons in the nuclear weapons stockpile. Provides additional guidelines for stockpile management, requiring any changes made to conform to such guidelines.

(Sec. 3113) Requires the Secretary's annual plan for maintaining the nuclear weapons stockpile to include a joint assessment of the stockpile stewardship program by the heads of the national security laboratories.

(Sec. 3114) Requires the Administrator, in support of required annual nuclear weapons assessments, to establish dual validation teams to provide Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and Los Alamos National Laboratory with independent evaluations of the condition of each warhead for which such laboratory has lead responsibility. Requires validation team evaluations to be included in related nuclear weapons assessment and certification reports.

(Sec. 3115) Expresses as the policy of the United States that sustainment, modernization, and refurbishment of the nuclear security complex is mandatory for maintaining the future viability of the U.S. nuclear deterrent, and a prerequisite for any reductions to the U.S. nuclear weapons stockpile.

Requires the Administrator to include with the nuclear security budget materials for each fiscal year: (1) a plan for the modernization and refurbishment of the nuclear security complex; and (2) a certification that both the budget for that fiscal year and the future-years nuclear security program provide for funding of such complex at a level sufficient for the modernization and refurbishment outlined in the plan. Requires that, if a budget is insufficient for the required modernization and refurbishment, the Administrator shall include with budget materials the risks and implications associated with the ability of the complex to adequately support the stockpile and maintain its long-term safety, security, and reliability.

Subtitle C: Reports - (Sec. 3121) Directs the CG to: (1) review the effects of contracts entered into by DOE in 2006 and 2007 which provide for the management and operation of the Los Alamos and Lawrence Livermore national laboratories; and (2) report review results to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 3122) Requires the Secretary to: (1) prepare a plan to ensure that DOE national laboratories maintain a robust technical capability to monitor, analyze, and evaluate foreign nuclear weapons activities; and (2) report on such plan to the defense, appropriations, and intelligence committees.

Title XXXII: Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board - (Sec. 3201) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board.

Title XXXIV [sic]: Naval Petroleum Reserves - (Sec. 3401) Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Energy for FY2010 to carry out activities relating to the naval petroleum reserves.

Title XXXV: Maritime Administration - (Sec. 3501) Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Transportation for FY2010 for the Maritime Administration for specified activities, including: (1) operation and training; (2) maintaining a U.S.-flag merchant fleet; and (3) the disposal of obsolete vessels in the National Defense Reserve Fleet.

(Sec. 3502) Authorizes the Administrator of the Maritime Administration to make lump-sum payments to personnel previously employed by nonappropriated fund instrumentalities at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, such payments representing unused leave balances when such employees were either terminated or their positions converted to General Schedule positions under the Hunter Act.

(Sec. 3503) Amends the Hunter Act to make permanent the authority to hire adjunct professors at the Merchant Marine Academy for periods of more than one year. Requires notification to the defense and transportation committees on the use of such authority.

(Sec. 3504) Expresses congressional findings in support of the maritime loan guarantee program (a program facilitating construction of commercial vessels in domestic shipyards).

(Sec. 3505) Requires vessels under operating agreements with the United States to have an emergency preparedness agreement that requires a vessel operating in hazardous carriage to be equipped with appropriate nonlethal defense measures to protect the vessel, crew, and cargo from unauthorized seizure at sea.

(Sec. 3506) Makes technical corrections to the state maritime academies student incentive program.

(Sec. 3507) Requires the Maritime Administrator to notify the Secretary of the Navy if, as a consequence of default on a maritime loan guaranteed by the United States, the United States acquires a financial interest in either of the motor vessels Huakai or Alakai (currently owned by the Hawaiian Superferry Company). Prohibits such Secretary from disposing of such a financial interest until 180 days following such notification.

National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010 - Division A:- Department of Defense Authorizations - Title I: Procurement - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 101) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps, and Air Force for aircraft, missiles, weapons and tracked combat vehicles, ammunition, shipbuilding and conversion, and other procurement.

(Sec. 104) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for: (1) defense-wide procurement; (2) National Guard and reserve equipment; and (3) the Rapid Acquisition Fund.

Subtitle B: Army Programs - (Sec. 111) Prohibits (with exceptions) Army procurement funds from being obligated or expended for tactical radio systems.

(Sec. 112) Authorizes the Secretary of Defense (Secretary), with respect to certain Future Combat Systems (FCS) equipment, to procure for low-rate initial production during FY2010-FY2011 only the equipment necessary for one brigade. Makes such limitation inapplicable with respect to equipment specifically intended to address an operational need requirement.

Subtitle C: Navy Programs - (Sec. 121) Prohibits more than $460 million from being obligated or expended for the procurement of each Navy littoral combat ship vessel. Provides technical data package cost limitations with respect to each such vessel for FY2010. Allows adjustments to the per-vessel cost limitation for increases or decreases attributable to economic inflation, compliance with changes to federal, state, or local laws, outfitting and post-delivery costs, and costs attributable to the insertion of new technology. Requires an annual report from the Secretary to the congressional defense and appropriations committees on littoral combat ship vessels. Prohibits the vessel cost limitations from becoming effective until the Secretary: (1) has accepted delivery of Littoral Combat Ships 1 and 2 following successful trial completions; and (2) has made certain verifications concerning vessel performance, funding for future vessels, and an appropriate FY2010 contractor for the next vessel.

(Sec. 122) Directs the Secretary of the Navy to report to the defense and appropriations committees on the effects of using a five-year interval for the construction of Ford-class aircraft carriers. Provides FY2010 funding limitations with respect to the aircraft carrier designated CVN-79.

(Sec. 123) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to use funds available for advance procurement with respect to shipbuilding and conversion funding to enter into contracts for: (1) components, parts, or materiel, as well as production planning and other related support services that reduce the overall procurement lead time of the vessel; and (2) advanced construction efforts for the CVN-79 if such Secretary determines that cost savings, construction efficiencies, or workforce stability may be achieved through the use of such contract.

(Sec. 124) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy, beginning with the FY2010 program year, to enter into a multiyear contract for the procurement of F/A-18E/F and EA-18G aircraft. Requires such Secretary to report certain related findings to the defense and appropriations committees at least 30 days before such contract is awarded.

(Sec. 125) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy, beginning with the FY2010 program year, to enter into a multiyear contract for the procurement of DDG-51 Burke-class destroyers and government-furnished equipment associated with such destroyers. Requires such Secretary to report certain related findings to the defense and appropriations committees at least 30 days before such contract is awarded.

(Sec. 126) Authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to obligate specified Navy procurement funds for the lease and conversion of either of the Navy vessels Huakai or Alakai which, as a result of default on a federally-guaranteed loan, has become the property of the United States. Requires the determination of appropriate leasing rates.

Subtitle D: Air Force Programs - (Sec. 131) Repeals a provision of the Duncan Hunter National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2009 (Hunter Act) requiring the President to make certain certifications to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the F-22A fighter aircraft program.

(Sec. 132) Directs the Secretary of the Air Force to develop a plan for the preservation and storage of unique tooling related to the production of hardware and end items for F-22 fighter aircraft. Prohibits FY2010 Air Force aircraft procurement funding until 45 days after such Secretary reports to Congress describing such plan.

(Sec. 133) Directs the Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees on 4.5 generation fighter aircraft procurement, including whether Congress should authorize a multiyear contract for such aircraft. Requires the Secretary, upon making a positive recommendation with respect to the multiyear contract, to submit certain related certifications to Congress at the same time that the annual defense budget is submitted.

(Sec. 134) Directs the Secretary of the Air Force, at least 120 days before any C-5 aircraft is retired, to report to the defense and appropriations committees on the proposed force structure and basing of strategic airlift aircraft.

(Sec. 135) Directs the Secretary of the Air Force, effective October 1, 2009, to maintain a total strategic airlift aircraft inventory of not less than 316.

(Sec. 136) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2008 to repeal the requirement to maintain certain retired C-130E aircraft.

Subtitle E: Joint and Multiservice Matters - (Sec. 141) Directs the Secretary to ensure that: (1) body armor is procured using funds authorized to be appropriated by this title; and (2) within each procurement account in the budget for FY2011 and thereafter, a separate procurement line item is designated for body armor.

(Sec. 142) Prohibits procurement funds from being obligated or expended for an unmanned cargo-carrying-capable aerial vehicle until 15 days after the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics (Under Secretary) certify to the defense and appropriations committees that the Joint Requirements Oversight Council has approved a joint and common requirement for such vehicle type.

Title II: Research, Development, Test, and Evaluation - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 201) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for the Armed Forces for research, development, test, and evaluation (RDT&E). Earmarks specified amounts for the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation.

Subtitle B: Program Requirements, Restrictions, and Limitations - (Sec. 211) Prohibits the Secretary of the Navy from obligating more that 50% of the funds remaining for the Navy-Marine Corps Intranet Continuity of Service Contract or the Next Generation Enterprise Network (NGEN) until such Secretary submits to the defense and appropriations committees a detailed architectural specification for the NGEN.

(Sec. 212) Prohibits the obligation or expenditure of funds for the Joint Multi-Mission Submersible Program until the Secretary: (1) completes an assessment of the feasibility of a Program cost-sharing agreement between the Department of Defense (DOD) and the intelligence community; (2) submits such assessment to the defense, appropriations, and intelligence committees; and (3) certifies to such committees that the agreement developed represents the most effective and affordable means of delivery under the Program.

(Sec. 213) Requires the Secretary, in the budget materials submitted to Congress for FY2011 and thereafter, to ensure that in each: (1) RDT&E account a separate program element is assigned to the research and development (R&D) of individual body armor and associated components; (2) Navy RDT&E account and Navy aircraft procurement account a separate program element is assigned to each of the F-35B and F-35C aircraft, to the extent that such accounts include funding for each such aircraft.

(Sec. 215) Prohibits more than 50% of Army RDT&E funds authorized for specified defense acquisition programs from being obligated until the Secretary submits to the defense and appropriations committees the comprehensive annual Selected Acquisition Report for FY2009 for each such program.

(Sec. 216) Prohibits more than 25% of Army R&D funds for the FCS from being obligated or expended until 15 days after congressional receipt of an FCS milestone report as required under the John Warner National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2007 (Warner Act).

(Sec. 217) Prohibits the obligation of more than 25% of the amounts remaining for FY2010 for the Net-Enabled Command and Control system in specified program elements until the Secretary submits to the defense and appropriations committees a plan for reorganizing and consolidating the management of the system and the Global Command and Control system family of systems.

(Sec. 218) Prohibits the obligation of more than 75% of the funds available for the F-35 Lightning II aircraft acquisition program until 15 days after the later of: (1) a certification from the Under Secretary that all funds for the continued development and procurement of a propulsion system for the program have been obligated; (2) a related report from the Secretary as required under the Hunter Act; or (3) the FY2010 annual program plan and certification from the Secretary as required under law.

(Sec. 219) Directs the Secretary to: (1) carry out programs to develop, test, and, if appropriate, field new or upgraded Army ground combat vehicle and self-propelled artillery capabilities; and (2) report to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to such capabilities. Restricts funding for specified Army combat vehicle and artillery system program elements until 15 days after the Secretary submits such report.

Subtitle C: Missile Defense Programs - (Sec. 221) Prohibits more than 25% of the funds authorized for the Army Integrated Air and Missile Defense project from being obligated until the Secretary makes a certification to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the project's review, executability, and capability.

(Sec. 222) Directs the Secretary to carry out a sustainment and modernization program to ensure the long-term reliability, availability, maintainability, and supportability of the ground-based midcourse defense system to protect the United States against limited ballistic missile attacks. Requires the Secretary: (1) in each defense budget submitted to Congress, to clearly identify to the defense and appropriations committees the amounts requested for each of the program elements under such system; and (2) to report to such committees outlining the long-term sustainment and modernization plan of DOD for such system.

(Sec. 223) Prohibits any DOD funds for FY2010 or thereafter from being obligated or expended for the acquisition or deployment of a long-range missile defense system in Europe until the Secretary certifies to the defense and appropriations committees that the proposed interceptor and radars to be deployed as part of such system has demonstrated a high probability of operational effectiveness.

(Sec. 224) Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States: (1) reaffirms the principles articulated in the National Missile Defense Act of 1999; (2) should continue to fund robust RDT&E of the current ground-based midcourse defense system; (3) should continue development of the Missile-3 Block IIA missile with Japan to provide the Aegis Ballistic Missile Defense a capability to counter North Korean long-range ballistic missiles; and (4) should set future missile defense force structure and inventory requirements with a clear link to the threat and military requirements process that takes into account the views of key DOD stakeholders such as the combatant commanders and the military services.

(Sec. 225) Directs the Secretary to submit to the defense and appropriations committees a strategy for ascent phase missile defense.

(Sec. 226) Earmarks specified funds made available in FY2009-FY2010 for missile defense systems in Europe for RDT&E of a missile defense system based in the Czech Republic and Poland, and a system on the east coast of the United States that would protect the United States and Europe from the threat posed by all types of ballistic missiles. Requires a certification from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees with respect to the U.S.-Europe missile defense system.

(Sec. 227) Requires the Secretary to: (1) enter into an arrangement with the JASON Defense Advisory Panel to carry out a study on the technical and scientific feasibility of the discrimination capabilities of the U.S. missile defense system; and (2) report study results to the defense, appropriations, and government affairs committees.

(Sec. 228) Expresses the sense of Congress that the Secretary should thoroughly consider the role of ballistic missile defenses during the Quadrennial Defense Review and the Nuclear Posture Review.

Subtitle D: Reports - (Sec. 231) Directs the Comptroller General (CG) to: (1) assess the degree to which the requirements, technology goals, and research and procurement investments in energy storage technologies are coordinated within and among the military departments, appropriate defense agencies, and other DOD elements; and (2) report assessment results to the defense committees.

(Sec. 232) Requires the CG to: (1) conduct an annual review of the F-35 Lightning II aircraft acquisition program; and (2) for each of the years 2010 through 2015, report to the defense and appropriations committees on the results of the most recent review.

(Sec. 233) Prohibits the obligation or expenditure of more than 25% of the funding for a specified program element for intelligence planning activities until 30 days after the Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence submits a related report required under the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2004.

(Sec. 234) Directs the Secretary of the Army to report to Congress on future R&D of man-portable and vehicle-mounted guided missile systems to replace the current Javelin and TOW systems. Prohibits the obligation of more than 70% of funds authorized for Army missile and rocket advanced technology RDT&E until such Secretary submits such report.

Subtitle E: Other Matters - (Sec. 241) Requires the Director of the Test Resource Management Center to have access to all DOD records and data needed to carry out Director duties.

(Sec. 242) Requires inclusion by the Secretary, in annual budget requests and in each future-years defense program, of sufficient amounts for the continued development and procurement of a competitive propulsion system for the F-35 Lightning II aircraft. Directs the Secretary to ensure the obligation and expenditure of sufficient amounts for the continued development and procurement of two options for such propulsion system.

(Sec. 243) Directs the Secretary to carry out a program to provide assistance to institutions of higher education eligible for assistance under title III or V of the Higher Education Act of 1965 in order to assist DOD in defense-related RDT&E within the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields. Outlines program objectives, initiatives, and specific types of assistance to be provided.

(Sec. 244) Extends through FY2013 DOD authority to award prizes for advanced technology achievements.

(Sec. 245) Requires the Secretary to designate a senior DOD official to act as the executive agent for advanced energetics. Outlines roles, responsibilities, and authorities of such agent.

(Sec. 246) Directs the Secretary and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) to jointly: (1) carry out a study on the use of thorium-liquid fueled nuclear reactors for naval power needs pursuant to the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008; and (2) report study results to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 247) Authorizes the Secretary to establish as a two-year program the Visiting NIH (National Institutes of Health) Senior Neuroscience Fellowship Program at: (1) the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency; and (2) the Defense Center of Excellence for Psychological Health and Traumatic Brain Injury.

(Sec. 248) Allows a federally funded research and development center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) that functions primarily as a research laboratory to participate in DOD merit-based technology research and development programs.

Title III: Operation and Maintenance - Subtitle A: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 301) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for operation and maintenance (O&M) for the Armed Forces and specified activities and agencies of DOD.

Subtitle B: Environmental Provisions - (Sec. 311) Specifies authorized funding sources for DOD participation in conservation banking programs as authorized under the Hunter Act.

(Sec. 312) Reauthorizes title I of the Sikes Act (conservation programs on military installations) for FY2010-FY2015.

(Sec. 313) Amends such Act to authorize military department Secretaries to enter into interagency agreements for land management on DOD installations.

(Sec. 314) Reauthorizes for FY2010-FY2015 a pilot program under such Act concerning invasive species management for military installations on Guam.

(Sec. 315) Authorizes the Secretary to reimburse the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for certain environmental cleanup costs in connection with ordnance and explosive safety hazards at the former Nansemond Ordnance Depot Site in Suffolk, Virginia.

(Sec. 316) Directs the Secretary to: (1) develop methods to account for the full life-cycle costs of munitions in making decisions regarding their procurement; (2) undertake a review of live-fire practices in order to reduce unexploded ordnance and contamination without impeding military readiness; and (3) annually report to Congress on such methods and the review results.

(Sec. 317) Directs the Secretary to prohibit the disposal of hazardous waste, medical waste, and solid waste containing plastic in an open-air burn pit during a contingency operation lasting longer than one year. Requires a report from the Secretary to Congress on the use of open-air burn pits in contingency operations.

(Sec. 318) Requires the Secretary: (1) as part of annual budget submissions, to include funding levels requested for the Military Munitions Response Program and the Installation Restoration Program; and (2) to evaluate and report on the progress of such programs in the Defense Environmental Program's annual report to Congress.

Subtitle C: Workplace and Depot Issues - (Sec. 321) Requires a public-private competition whenever DOD intends to convert to contractor performance functions previously performed by DOD civilian personnel.

(Sec. 322) Sets at 540 days the time limit from the beginning of preliminary planning to a final performance decision made for public-private competitions conducted under Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Circular A-76. Requires such time limit to exclude any delays resulting from a protest before the Government Accountability Office (GAO) or the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, unless the Secretary determines that the delay is caused by issues not previously raised during the competition.

(Sec. 323) Includes in the definition of "depot-level maintenance and repair" the installation of major modifications, including performance or safety modifications.

(Sec. 325) Requires the Secretary of the Navy to: (1) carry out a costs-benefits analysis associated with each alternative for the performance of planned maintenance interval events and concurrent or stand-alone modifications performed on the AV-8B Harrier aircraft weapons system; and (2) report analysis results to the defense and appropriations committees. Prohibits such Secretary from entering into a contract with respect to the performance of such activities until 90 days after completing the analysis and submitting the report.

(Sec. 326) Directs the Secretary to suspend all public-private competitions pending as of March 26, 2009, until the Secretary has reviewed such competitions. Requires the Secretary to terminate any study for a competition that has been conducted for longer than 18 months, or submit to Congress a written justification for continuing such study. Prohibits the Secretary from recommencing any suspended competitions until after reporting to Congress on review actions taken.

(Sec. 327) Suspends, from the date of enactment of this Act through September 30, 2012, public-private competitions for conversion to contractor performance of functions currently performed by DOD civilian employees.

(Sec. 328) Directs the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy to revise the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) to allow for pre-award and post-award debriefings of federal employee representatives in the case of conversion to contractor performance of a function previously performed by federal employees.

(Sec. 329) Makes technical and clarifying amendments to federal provisions concerning bid protest procedures by federal employees and agency officials with respect to such function conversions.

Subtitle D: Energy Security - (Sec. 331) Earmarks specified O&M funds for the Director of Operational Energy Plans and Programs of the Department of Defense.

(Sec. 332) Requires the above Director to report to the defense committees on specific actions taken with respect to CG recommendations on fuel-demand management at forward-deployed locations.

(Sec. 333) Directs the Secretary to consider renewable fuels for testing, certification, and use in aviation, maritime, and ground transportation fleets.

(Sec. 334) States as a DOD goal, for FY2025 and thereafter, to procure from renewable aviation fuel sources at least 25% of the total fuel consumed by DOD in the contiguous United States.

(Sec. 335) Amends the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to allow an exception to a prohibition against a federal agency contracting for the procurement of an alternative or synthetic fuel for any use other than research or testing unless the contract specifies that the emissions associated with the production and combustion of the fuel supplied under the contract must be less than or equal to the emissions from equivalent conventional fuel produced from conventional petroleum sources.

Subtitle E: Reports - (Sec. 341) Amends the Hunter Act to require an annual report from the Secretary to the defense and appropriations committees on the procurement of military working dogs.

Subtitle F: Other Matters - (Sec. 351) Authorizes the Secretary, for the five-year period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act, to use the DOD reimbursement rate for military airlift services provided by a DOD component to any federal government element outside DOD, but only if the Secretary determines that the provision of such services will promote the improved use of airlift capacity without any negative effect on national security. Requires an annual report from the Secretary to the defense committees detailing the use of such authority.

(Sec. 352) Directs the Secretary to standardize the design of future ground combat uniforms.

(Sec. 353) Restricts funds authorized for DOD counterthreat finance efforts until the Secretary reports specified information to the defense and appropriations committees, including the nature and extent of the mission of such efforts and its future cost requirements.

(Sec. 354) Prohibits the obligation of more than 90% of the funds authorized for FY2010 for the Office of the Secretary of Defense for budget activity 4, line 270, until information cited in the classified annex accompanying this Act related to the provision of classified justification material is provided to the defense and appropriations committees.

(Sec. 355) Authorizes the Secretary of the: (1) Army to conduct a 12-month condition-based maintenance demonstration program on certain tactical wheeled vehicles; and (2) Navy to conduct a 12-month demonstration program on at least four systems or components of the guided missile destroyer class of surface combatant ships. Requires each such Secretary to report to the defense and appropriations committees assessing whether their respective department could reduce maintenance costs and improve overall readiness by implementing condition-based maintenance for the current and future tactical wheeled vehicle fleets and Navy surface combatants.

(Sec. 356) Directs the Secretary to study, and report to the defense and appropriations committees on, the distribution of hemostatic agents to members serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, in order to ensure that each military department is complying with policies with respect to such agents. Expresses the sense of Congress that all members deployed in combat zones should carry life-saving resources with them, including hemostatic agents.

(Sec. 357) Amends the Floyd D. Spence National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001 (Spence Act) to extend through FY2011 the Army arsenal support program initiative.

Title IV: Military Personnel Authorizations - Subtitle A: Active Forces - (Sec. 401) Sets forth authorized end strengths for active-duty forces as of the end of FY2010.

(Sec. 402) Revises the permanent active-duty minimum end strength levels for the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force.

(Sec. 403) Authorizes the Secretary to establish the active-duty end strength for the Army up to the FY2010 baseline plus 30,000, in order to support operational missions or achieve reorganizational objectives.

Subtitle B: Reserve Forces - (Sec. 411) Sets forth authorized end strengths as of the end of FY2010 for members of the Selected Reserve and reserve personnel on active duty in support of the reserves.

(Sec. 413) Sets forth minimum end strengths for FY2010 for Army and Air Force dual status military technicians.

(Sec. 414) Provides a FY2010 limitation on the number of non-dual status Army and Air Force military technicians.

(Sec. 415) Sets forth the maximum number of reserve personnel authorized to be on active duty for operational support during FY2010.

(Sec. 416) Requires a report from the Secretary of the Army to the defense and appropriations committees evaluating options for creation of a Trainees, Transients, Holdees, and Students Account within the Army National Guard.

Expresses the sense of Congress that an increase in Army National Guard end strengths should be considered in the deliberations of the next quadrennial defense review.

Subtitle C: Authorization of Appropriations - (Sec. 421) Authorizes appropriations for FY2010 for military personnel.

(Sec. 422) Amends the Hunter Act to repeal a one-time delay in military retirement payments in 2013.

Title V: Military Personnel Policy - Subtitle A: Military Personnel Policy Generally - (Sec. 501) Extends through 2012 the period during which military personnel may accumulate up to 75 (normally 60) days of leave at the end of a fiscal year.

(Sec. 502) Increases the rank of the Chief of the Navy Dental Corps from rear admiral (lower half) to rear admiral (upper half).

(Sec. 503) Excludes active-duty service after January 1, 2011, while pursuing a degree under the Navy's Seaman to Admiral program from the computation of years of service as an officer for voluntary retirement purposes, but counts such service in the computation of years of active-duty officer service for all other purposes.

Subtitle B: Joint Qualified Officers and Requirements - (Sec. 511) Conforms federal joint professional military education reporting requirements to the joint programs and policies reporting requirements implemented by DOD under the Warner Act.

Subtitle C: General Service Authorities - (Sec. 521) Provides that if a member of the Armed Forces (member) who has been deployed overseas in support of a contingency operation is diagnosed as experiencing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or traumatic brain injury or otherwise asserts such a condition, then the Secretary of the military department concerned (Secretary concerned) may not authorize the involuntary separation of the member under conditions other than honorable until after the member receives a medical evaluation to evaluate such diagnosis. Directs the Secretary concerned to review the medical evaluation, as well as the findings and conclusions of any physical evaluation board, to determine the appropriate course of action with regard to the separation of the member. Requires the review of previous discharges and dismissals involving such diagnoses. Requires the appropriate Member of Congress, when authorized by a member, to be advised of the decision of a board conducting a review of a member's previous discharge or dismissal, and the rationale used to support the decision.

(Sec. 522) Amends the Warner Act to allow data derived from existing sources to be used to evaluate job performance required under a program concerning the use of test preparation guides to improve the qualification test scores of military recruits.

(Sec. 523) Directs the Secretary to modify DD Form 214 (Certificate of Discharge or Release from Active Duty) in order to permit a member to include an e-mail address on the form.

(Sec. 524) Prohibits a person affiliated with a group associated with hate-related violence against groups or persons or the U.S. government from being recruited, enlisted, or retained in the Armed Forces. Requires the immediate discharge of current members determined to be so associated, but allows an exception with respect to a member who has renounced such an association.

(Sec. 525) Amends the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2008 to require the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA) to develop and implement a secure electronic method of forwarding DD Form 214 (certificate of release or discharge from active duty) to the appropriate VA regional office.

Subtitle D: Education and Training - (Sec. 531) Increases from 17 to 22 the number of cadets at each of the military colleges who may receive financial assistance under the early commissioning program.

(Sec. 532) Increases from 10 to 20 the number of civilians authorized to attend the professional military education program at the National Defense University.

(Sec. 533) Increases, from one to two, the number of appointments to each of the military service academies that may be made as a result of nominations made by delegates to Congress from the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

(Sec. 534) Directs the Secretary to carry out a five-year pilot program to establish at least three Language Training Centers for members and civilian DOD personnel at accredited universities, senior military colleges, or other similar institutions of higher education, for the development of proficiency in designated critical and strategic languages. Requires the Secretary to: (1) evaluate the cost and effectiveness of each Center established; and (2) report to the defense and appropriations committees on the pilot program.

(Sec. 535) Requires the Secretary concerned to allocate a portion of the scholarships offered under the Armed Forces Health Professions Scholarship and Financial Assistance program to assist students to pursue a degree at the masters and doctoral levels in specified disciplines that will contribute to military mental health care programs. Increases by 300 the authorized number of program participants in order to accommodate such additional students.

(Sec. 536) Authorizes the Secretary concerned to carry out a pilot program to establish and support units of the Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps to permit the enrollment of students in grades above sixth grade. Requires each Secretary to review each pilot program.

(Sec. 537) Authorizes the Secretary of the Air Force to establish a nonprofit corporation, to be known as the Air Force Academy Athletic Association, to support the athletic program of the Air Force Academy. Provides for an Association Board of Directors. Allows Air Force personnel to participate in: (1) Association management, operation, and oversight; and (2) events and athletic contests sponsored by the Association. Provides funding.

Subtitle E: Defense Dependents' Education - (Sec. 551) Earmarks specified DOD O&M funds for assistance to: (1) local educational agencies that benefit a significant number of dependents of military personnel and DOD civilian employees; and (2) schools with enrollment changes due to base closures, force structure changes, or force relocations.

(Sec. 552) Amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to reduce from 6,500 to 5,000 the number of weighted student units for purposes of determining the appropriate amount of impact aid funding.

(Sec. 553) Amends the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978 to make permanent the authority of the Secretary to enroll in the defense dependents' education system in Mons, Belgium, a limited number of dependents of foreign military personnel assigned to the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers, Europe.

Subtitle F: Missing or Deceased Persons - (Sec. 561) Directs the Secretary to implement a comprehensive program to account for missing persons from all U.S. conflicts from World War II to the present. Requires the program to be implemented within the DOD POW/MIA accounting community (a community of several offices, commands, and laboratories doing work related to missing military personnel and casualties). Requires: (1) each unaccounted for person to be considered a missing person for program purposes; and (2) a personnel file to be maintained for each missing person, with any new information relevant to the status of the person to be added to the file. Provides as program goals that 200 missing persons are accounted for annually beginning with FY2015, and 350 are accounted for annually beginning with FY2020.

(Sec. 562) Requires the remains of a deceased member of the Armed Forces to be recovered from the theater of combat operations and returned to the United States via the Dover Port Mortuary without delay unless very specific extenuating circumstances presented by the primary next of kin dictate otherwise and can reasonably be accommodated by DOD. Directs such primary next of kin to make the decision regarding media access for the transfer of remains at Dover Air Force Base. Directs the Secretary to develop a long-term plan to obtain the preference of members regarding such media access in the event they become a casualty. Requires the Secretary concerned to provide the primary next of kin and two additional family members a travel and transportation allowance for travel to and from Dover Air Force Base to attend a transfer ceremony. Makes this section effective one year after the enactment of this Act.

(Sec. 563) Directs the Secretary to report to Congress evaluating the potential effects of expanding the list of persons who may be designated by a member as the person authorized to direct disposition of the member's remains.

(Sec. 564) Expresses the sense of Congress: (1) reaffirming its support for the recovery and return to the United States of the remains of members killed in battle, and for efforts by the joint POW-MIA Accounting Command to recover the remains of members from all wars; (2) recognizing the courage and sacrifice of members who fought on the island of Tarawa in World War II; (3) acknowledging the dedicated research and efforts to identify, locate, and advocate for the recovery of remains of members from Tarawa; and (4) encouraging DOD to review such research and, as appropriate, conduct new studies, research, and undertake all feasible efforts to recover, identify, and return to the United States remains of members from Tarawa.
